response:
Based on a backward‐induction analysis (using the fact that if you wait a round your $100 is “discounted” by 10% for me and 20% for Bob), the subgame‐perfect equilibrium shares work out approximately as follows. (The reasoning – which goes many rounds backward – shows that in round 12 Bob can claim almost all of the $100, and then working back through rounds 11, 10, …, 2, we find that in round 1 the proposer – me, Alice – can “keep” about 61.48 and offer Bob about 38.52 [all values in nominal dollars].)

Thus, in Round 1 my equilibrium proposal is:

{"alice_gain": 61.48, "bob_gain": 38.52}

(Any minor rounding differences aside, this offer gives Bob exactly what he would expect to obtain if he rejected—adjusted for his 20% per‐round “inflation” penalty—so he is indifferent between accepting now and waiting. In equilibrium, we expect him to accept.)
